lines.content: I mostly used Github Copilot and ChatGPT for this project.
- Create a name and personality for the chatbot
- Generate code based on a design specification
- Review code (to keep the AI updated and receive feedback)
What I did not ask AI:
- Recreate the full code on each iteration or request
- Code design and overall structure (class hierarchy etc)
- Any SDLC and version control related ideas
I notice the AI struggles with an iterative approach. It is unable to keep track of the project contents and structure
very well, and sometimes generates code that does not integrate very well into the existing structure, potentially
causing bugs. Another issue is that AI is unable to plan ahead, so iteratively adding changes via AI will often result
in unnecessary or badly structured code piling up. Therefore, I have to regularly review (and restructure) existing
code and keep the AI up to date with these changes.
As the project gets larger and more divided, it becomes harder and harder to track the overall progress and structure
using AI. Therefore, from here on, I mostly used AI to help generate smaller bits of independent code, a good example
being parsing methods. Otherwise, I also used AI to write the instructions in the in-program user guide. I tried using
it for documentation, but I preferred to write it myself since I have a better idea of my own intentions.
I used AI a lot to help me with designing and writing code for the GUI.
This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 17, update Intellij to the most recen![Screenshot 2025-09-15 141956.png](../../OneDrive/Pictures/Screenshots/Screenshot%202025-09-15%20141956.png)t version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 17** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

1. After that, locate the `src/main/java/lynx.TaskLynx.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run lynx.TaskLynx.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:

**Warning:** Keep the `src\main\java` folder as the root folder for Java files (i.e., don't rename those folders or move Java files to another folder outside of this folder path), as this is the default location some tools (e.g., Gradle) expect to find Java files.

TaskLynx is your reliable partner for keeping track of your tasks and activities.
TaskLynx provides an in-app command guide which displays information on the valid command usages.
Type `help` in the app to access this guide whenever you need to refer to it.
- todo tasks that support a description
- deadline tasks that support a description and a deadline
- event tasks that support a description, a start time and an end time
TaskLynx also lets you attach an optional priority to tasks!
TaskLynx allows you to view your tasks, based on:
Here are all tasks containing keyword "a":
Using the same variety of search modifiers as mentioned under "Listing tasks"!
Removed all tasks occurring on Nov 12 2025 00:00:
TaskLynx allows you to save your tasks to a data file using `save` and retrieve them anytime using `reload`.
TaskLynx also does this automatically when closing and opening the app, respectively.
For advanced users, TaskLynx lets you chain search modifiers for more specificity in your actions!

* Returns the TaskLynx user guide as a string.
reload                    - Load tasks from data file to task list (destructively)
save                      - Save task list to data file (destructively)
bye                       - Save and exit the program
* Creates a data file first if not found
* Date format: yyyy-mm-dd, yyyy-mm-dd-hh, or yyyy-mm-dd-hh-mm
* Priority can be optionally set using /p [priority] at the end of the command
Task actions (requires one or more search modifier(s)):
unmark                    - Unmark task(s) as not done
/key [keyword]            - Tasks with names containing the keyword
/on [date]                - Tasks occurring on a specific date
/all                      - All tasks in the task list
* Arguments must not contain blank characters, keywords included
list /key meeting         - Show all tasks containing 'meeting'
list /on 2025-09-01       - Show tasks occurring on 1st September 2025
delete /status complete   - Delete all tasks marked as completed
mark /p 1                 - Mark all tasks with priority 1
mark /id 3                - Mark the task with id 3 as done
unmark /all               - Unmark all tasks as not done
* [1][D][I] Attend a Coding Course by John (by: Sep 1 2025 00:00) (id:1)
